title: Kenya's contemporary Christianity: its nature and role
abstractText: Christianity is now predominantly a third world religion. Its form cannot simply be presumed to replicate 'mission' Christianity. In Africa, various forces are having their effect on the ways Christianity is understood, experienced and practised: among them, the traditional religious imagination, traditional cultural values and norms, traditions social form, rivalry with Islam, economic collapse, pressure of globalisation. Such factors have influenced the way Christianity is shaped but also the resulting religion is having considerable influence on local society, particularly where civil society is not thriving.
